awd_titl_txt: From Radio to Gamma-Rays: Interpreting the Multiwavelength Emission from Young Supernovae as a Probe of their Evolution, Progenitors, and Cosmic-Ray Acceleration
awd_abstract_narration:
When a massive star explodes as a supernova (SN), the shock wave from the explosion interacts with the material around the star, which has been ejected by the wind from the star during its lifetime. The rapidly moving shock wave heats this medium to high temperatures, and accelerates subatomic particles to high energies, thus producing radiation at all energies from low-energy radio waves to very high-energy gamma rays. A research group at the University of Chicago will study these interactions through computer simulations. They will interpret the signatures of the emitted radiation to infer the nature of the ambient medium with which the shocks interact, which can be related to the type of star that exploded. This will allow the investigators to relate the wide diversity of types of SNe to their different progenitor stars, helping to solve a very important problem in SNe and stellar astronomy. The researchers will also study the gamma rays emitted from young SNe. The project will provide research opportunities for undergraduate students, and one high school student each summer will be selected to work at the University of Chicago on supernova research. The lead scientists will also work with local school teachers to improve science education and give astronomy lectures to non-scientific audiences.

Using sophisticated emission routines, including non-equilibrium ionization X-ray calculations, a radio synchrotron emission code, optical light curve fitting using the computer programs MESA and STELLA, and other available routines, the team will compute the X-ray, radio and optical emission arising from the interaction of the SN shock with the ambient medium. The programs will be used to fine-tune the models of the circumstellar medium structure, which in turn can be used to estimate the mass-loss properties of the progenitor, constrain ejecta parameters, and determine explosion parameters.  Coupling to descriptions of mass-loss mechanisms will allow the investigators to probe the properties of the progenitor star. The detailed kinematic information from their models will be used to understand the acceleration of particles to relativistic energies in SN shocks, and predict the gamma-ray emission, which can be directly compared with data from ground and space-based telescopes. This project advances the goals of the NSF Windows on the Universe Big Idea.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This aim of this proposal was to investigate the radiation signatures resulting from the interaction of a supernovae (SN) shock wave with the pre-SN environment. Using a suite of emission routines that we developed and continue to improve we interpreted the emission from SNe in the radio, optical and X-ray regimes. The results enabled us to infer the nature of the medium surrounding the SN, and the properties of the progenitor star.

Simultaneously, we studied the acceleration of particles and gamma-ray emission from young SNe. Our calculations took into account the interaction of gamma-ray photons with soft optical photons to form electron-positron pairs.  We investigated the gamma ray visibility of young SNe with the upcoming Cerenkov Telescope Array (CTA) telescope.

Our major results are:

 Intellectual merit:
1. SN 1993J would likely not have been detected with existing gamma-ray observatories. The probability of detection of a similar SN with the CTA peaks 1 day before, or 10 days after the explosion.
2. Magnetic-field damping and stochastic re-acceleration can explain the high energy spectrum from Tycho's supernova remnant.
3. The oldest known X-ray SNe all have similar X-ray luminosities within two orders of magnitude. The luminosity is declining in time. If it continued to do so it would fall below that of known supernova remnants. However we show that the luminosity should start increasing as the SN transitions to the Sedov stage.
4. The X-ray flux from SN 1970G does not increase after 40 years, as mentioned in a previous paper. We do not see signs of an existing pulsar wind nebula.
5. Modeling of the multiwavelength spectrum of Cas A gives a minimum magnetic field inside the remnant of 150 μG, and provides evidence for proton acceleration to > 1 TeV.
6. We have studied the X-ray emission from SNR W49B using the Smooth Particle Inference technique, which allows us to compute the abundance distribution over the entire remnant. Comparing this distribution to SN explosion models suggests that W49B had a Type Ia progenitor.
7. The centroid of the Fe Kalpha line of the entire remnant is not always a solid indicator of the SN type (core-collapse or Ia), although it has been used as such in the past. Our results show that the Fe Kα centroid can vary over individual regions within the remnant, and the values can differ from the centroid of the overall remnant, sometimes substantially.  
8. Using an ionization-gasdynamics code, we have modelled wind-blown bubbles around massive stars. Our work shows that unlike the standard Weaver et al. (1977) picture that is normally assumed, the bubbles are not energy conserving but may lose energy over their evolution.
9. Our study of Type IIP SNe indicates that they will not be observable with the CTA except in galaxies less than 1 Mpc away.
10. A study of the X-ray, radio, IR and optical emission from SN 2014c suggests that the medium surrounding the SN was a two-component medium, which is denser at the equator due to the formation of a disk or torus, and less dense away from the equator. The shock interacting with the dense medium gives rise to the increasing X-ray and radio emission.
11. Our investigations suggest that X-ray SNRs in the Large Magellanic Clouds (LMC) can be better understood, provided younger LMC remnants are still expanding within wind-blown bubbles, and the average LMC density is about 1/3 that of our Galaxy.
12. Chandra space satellite observations of 3 SNe with an Halpha line in their optical spectrum, SN 2018fhw, SN 2018cqj and SN 2016jae, have detected no sign of X-ray emission from the SNe. We suggest it is because the observations were taken a few years after outburst, when the density had decreased, and that it would be better if observations were taken earlier, when the Halpha line was still visible.

Broader Impact:

1. We have trained 16 students, including 13 undergraduate and 3 Masters degree students.

2. One undergraduate student won a Chambliss award for his AAS meeting poster.

3. Undergraduate students wrote 5 first author papers. One Master's student wrote a first author paper, another was a co-author on a paper.

4. 6 undergraduate students have gone to grad school - Two to Caltech, one to Princeton, one to MIT, one to CMU for computer science, and one to University of Central Florida. Two received NSF fellowships. 

5. We made our X-ray lightcurves database accessible.

6. The PI started the Chicago Astronomy Research Mentoring (CHARM) project. During the first year, every 4 weeks he taught topics in stellar evolution and the deaths of stars to 17 minority students in the Junior High Physics class at the UC Woodlawn charter school, part of the Chicago Public Schools system. Subsequently he was delivering 2 lectures a semester to students at Joliet Junior College.
